<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 765, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 597]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 522, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 195, 532, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 237, 520, 253]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 263, 556, 295]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 603, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 380, 532, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{v\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 426, 532, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 469, 623, 488]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 501, 593, 520]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 530, 522, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 570, 527, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 593, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 623, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 512, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 556, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 750, 576, 768]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 778, 532, 812]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 361, 215]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 606, 245]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 443, 660, 462]]<|/det|>
The stress \(\sigma\) in the wire is calculated by using the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 469, 539, 500]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
A thin disc of radius \(r\) is supported at its centre O by a pin. The disc is supported so that it is vertical. Three forces act in the plane of the disc, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 434, 530, 453]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
Two horizontal and opposite forces, each of magnitude 1.2N, act at points A and B on the edge of the disc. A force of 6.0N, at an angle \(\theta\) below the horizontal, acts on the midpoint C of a radial line of the disc, as shown in Fig. 2.1. The disc has negligible weight and is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 181, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 543, 920, 577]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 588, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<form>.................................................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 180, 638]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 621, 606, 640]]<|/det|>
Friction between the disc and the pin is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 384, 655]]<|/det|>
Determine the angle \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 790, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... ° [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 822, 180, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 822, 643, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 915, 920, 932]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A spring is attached at one end to a fixed point and hangs vertically with a cube attached to the other end. The cube is initially held so that the spring has zero extension, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 114, 861, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 348, 450, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[742, 348, 811, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
The cube has weight 4.0N and sides of length 5.1cm. The cube is released and sinks into water as the spring extends. The cube reaches equilibrium with its base at a depth of 7.0cm below the water surface, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 443, 445]]<|/det|>
The density of the water is \(1000 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 458, 144, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
Calculate the difference in the pressure exerted by the water on the bottom face and on the top face of the cube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 642, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<form>difference in pressure = ............................................... $Pa$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 146, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 674, 727, 693]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (a) to show that the upthrust on the cube is 1.3N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 844, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 897, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculate the force exerted on the spring by the cube when it is in equilibrium in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ....................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 724, 183]]<|/det|>
The spring obeys Hooke's law and has a spring constant of \(30 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 144, 430]]<|/det|>

The cube in the water is released from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 181, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 444, 568, 462]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 597, 920, 616]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 628, 920, 661]]<|/det|>

<mark>[Total: 12]

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 710, 89]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
A horizontal string is stretched between two fixed points X and Y. The string is made to vibrate vertically so that a stationary wave is formed. At one instant, each particle of the string is at its maximum displacement, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 918, 494]]<|/det|>
P and Q are two particles of the string. The string vibrates with a frequency of \(40\mathrm{Hz}\). Distance XY is \(2.0\mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 508, 181, 526]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 847, 920, 865]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Two vertical metal plates in a vacuum have a separation of \(4.0 \text{cm}\). A potential difference of \(2.0 \times 10^{2} \text{V}\) is applied between the plates. Fig. 5.1 shows a side view of this arrangement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 180, 824, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 445, 532, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
A smoke particle is in the uniform electric field between the plates. The particle has weight \(3.9 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\) and charge \(-8.0 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 183, 542]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 522, 732, 542]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 677, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 708, 181, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 707, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, draw labelled arrows to show the directions of the two forces acting on the smoke particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 569, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 285, 120]]<|/det|>
Determine

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 390, 151]]<|/det|>
1. the magnitude of \(F\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 272, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
<form>magnitude = ....................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 304, 485, 322]]<|/det|>
2. the angle of \(F\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<form>angle = ............................................................ °

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 412, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The electric field in **(b)** is switched on at time \(t = 0\) when the particle is at a horizontal displacement \(s = 2.0 \text{cm}\) from the left-hand plate. At time \(t = 0\) the horizontal velocity of the particle is zero. The particle is then moved by the electric field until it hits a plate at time \(t = T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the horizontal displacement \(s\) of the particle from the left-hand plate.

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 504, 90]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by an electric current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 769, 152]]<|/det|>
A metal wire has length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 160, 725, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 294, 374, 312]]<|/det|>
\(I\) is the current in the wire,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 310, 650, 327]]<|/det|>
\(n\) is the number of free electrons per unit volume in the wire,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 562, 343]]<|/det|>
\(v\) is the average drift speed of a free electron and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 342, 406, 359]]<|/det|>
\(e\) is the charge on an electron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 181, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 371, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
State, in terms of \(A\), \(e\), \(L\) and \(n\), an expression for the total charge of the free electrons in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 416, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<form>.................................................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 448, 181, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 791, 467]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (i) to show that the current \(I\) is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 479, 539, 497]]<|/det|>
\[I = nAve.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 666, 146, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 666, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
A metal wire in a circuit is damaged. The resistivity of the metal is unchanged but the cross- sectional area of the wire is reduced over a length of \(3.0 \text{mm}\), as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 710, 809, 855]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 867, 532, 885]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 898, 831, 916]]<|/det|>
The wire has diameter \(d\) at cross-section X and diameter \(0.69d\) at cross-section Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 914, 421, 932]]<|/det|>
The current in the wire is \(0.50 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 356, 89]]<|/det|>
Determine the ratio

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 95, 727, 112]]<|/det|>
average drift speed of free electrons at cross-section Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 109, 730, 127]]<|/det|>
average drift speed of free electrons at cross-section X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>ratio = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
The main part of the wire with cross-section X has a resistance per unit length of \(1.7 \times 10^{-2} \Omega \text{m}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 571, 337]]<|/det|>
For the damaged length of the wire, calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 475, 368]]<|/det|>
1. the resistance per unit length,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance per unit length = ................................................. \(\Omega \mathrm{m}^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 505, 405, 523]]<|/det|>
2. the power dissipated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<form>power = ....................................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 660, 180, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 660, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
The diameter of the damaged length of the wire is further decreased. Assume that the current in the wire remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 706, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
State and explain qualitatively the change, if any, to the power dissipated in the damaged length of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A stationary nucleus X decays by emitting a \(\beta^{+}\) particle to form a nucleus of carbon-13 ( \(^{13}_{6}\mathrm{C}\) ). An incomplete equation to represent this decay is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 119, 584, 140]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{X}\rightarrow \mathrm{^{13}_{6}C} + \mathrm{\beta^{+}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 680, 170]]<|/det|>
State the name of the class (group) of particles that includes \(\beta^{+}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 212, 146, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 445, 230]]<|/det|>
For nucleus X, state the number of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 245, 373, 262]]<|/det|>
protons, ......................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 276, 373, 293]]<|/det|>
neutrons. ....................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 276, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 146, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 306, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
The carbon-13 nucleus has a mass of \(2.2 \times 10^{-26} \text{kg}\). Its kinetic energy as a result of the decay process is \(0.80 \text{MeV}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 452, 370]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of this nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 590, 920, 608]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 622, 146, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 622, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
Explain why the sum of the kinetic energies of the carbon-13 nucleus and the \(\beta^{+}\) particle cannot be equal to the total energy released by the decay process.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 728, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
